description: From Middle English overture, from Anglo-Norman, Middle French overture, from Old French overture. Doublet of aperture.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) An opening; a recess or chamber. [15th–19th c.]
(often in plural) An approach or proposal made to initiate communication, establish a relationship etc. [from 15th c.]
(Scotland) A motion placed before a legislative body, such as the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland. [from 16th c.]
(music) A musical introduction to a piece of music, or a play. [from 17th c.]

verbs.description: overture (third-person singular simple present overtures, present participle overturing, simple past and past participle overtured)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make overtures; to approach with a proposal.
examples: For a partner setting a table in a game of “house,” an overturing child might assume the role of the father returning home from work at dinnertime rather than overturing by throwing a ball toward the child and yelling “catch.”
